content:
12. **Free Look Period** - If the Policy has been issued and for any reason whatsoever You decide not to take up the Policy, You can cancel Your Policy by notifying Us in writing within fourteen (14) days from the date of delivery of the Policy. We will refund the premium paid unless something has occurred for which a claim may be payable. The free look period will not apply to renewals of Your Policy with Us.
13. **Geographical Limits** - The coverage under this Policy is Twenty-four (24) hours a day, worldwide (excluding sanctioned countries as per condition 22) unless otherwise stated in the Policy, endorsed or amended.
14. **Governing Law** - Any interpretation of this Policy relating to its construction, validity or operation shall be made in accordance with the laws of Singapore.
questions: How does the Free Look Period allow for policy cancellation and premium refund, and what conditions related to claims or renewals affect this right?
In what ways do the geographical limits define worldwide coverage, and how do sanctioned countries as per condition 22 impact this coverage?
How does the Free Look Period interact with the occurrence of events that may give rise to claims within the 14-day cancellation window?
What is the significance of the policy being governed by Singapore law in terms of dispute resolution and interpretation of coverage terms?
If a policyholder receives the policy document but decides to cancel after 14 days, how does the Free Look Period clause affect their ability to obtain a refund?
How do endorsements or amendments to the policy modify the default geographical limits of worldwide coverage?
What are the implications of the Free Look Period not applying to policy renewals in terms of cancellation rights and premium refunds?
How does the exclusion of sanctioned countries under condition 22 interact with the general worldwide coverage provided 24 hours a day?
In a scenario where a claimable event occurs during the Free Look Period, how does this affect the policyholder's right to cancel and receive a refund?
How does the policyâ€™s governing law clause influence the interpretation of exclusions such as those related to sanctioned countries?
What documentation or notification requirements must be met within the 14-day Free Look Period to validly cancel the policy and obtain a refund?
How might amendments or endorsements override the standard geographical limits, and what process governs these changes under Singapore law?
If a policyholder travels to a sanctioned country unknowingly, how does the geographical limit exclusion affect their coverage and potential claims?
How does the Free Look Period clause address situations where the policyholder has already made a claim before deciding to cancel?
What legal recourse does a policyholder have under Singapore law if there is a dispute regarding the application of the Free Look Period or geographical limits?
How does the 24-hour worldwide coverage provision apply to incidents occurring during transit through multiple countries, including any sanctioned territories?
In what ways do the Free Look Period and geographical limits clauses collectively impact the timing and validity of claims made shortly after policy issuance?
How does the policy define the start of the Free Look Period in relation to the date of delivery, and what constitutes valid delivery under Singapore law?
What are the consequences for coverage if the policyholder attempts to cancel during the Free Look Period but fails to notify the insurer in writing within the required timeframe?
How do the Free Look Period, geographical limits, and governing law clauses together shape the overall rights and obligations of the policyholder and insurer?
